channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Founding Grateful Dead member dies at 78
item.description: Bob Weir, who helped build the Grateful Dead from the Haight-Ashbury scene into a cultural institution, has died at 78.
item.content:encoded: Bob Weir, who helped build the Grateful Dead from the Haight-Ashbury scene into a cultural institution, has died at 78.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Gomez Sarmiento

item.title: Iran protests enter third week under internet blackout
item.description: As Iran's protests enter a third week, the country's president blames foreign powers for the unrest, and warns it will retaliate if the US intervenes militarily.
item.content:encoded: As Iran's protests enter a third week, the country's president blames foreign powers for the unrest, and warns it will retaliate if the US intervenes militarily.
item.dc:creator: Willem Marx

item.title: Are you craving a stronger community?
item.description: NPR's Life Kit has tips on how to build your village.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Life Kit has tips on how to build your village.
item.dc:creator: Marielle Segarra

item.title: Trump promised a Gaza endgame. Palestinians say they are still living the war
item.description: Three months after Trump's Gaza plan, Palestinians say the war is still not over and no international force has arrived.
item.content:encoded: Three months after Trump's Gaza plan, Palestinians say the war is still not over and no international force has arrived.
item.dc:creator: Michele Kelemen

item.title: Supreme Court weighs bans on trans athletes in women's and girls' sports teams
item.description: The Supreme Court hears two cases this week on state bans for trans athletes playing on women's and girls' sports teams. Kate Sosin, who covers LGBTQ issues for the non-profit newsroom The 19th, has been following these cases closely.
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court hears two cases this week on state bans for trans athletes playing on women's and girls' sports teams. Kate Sosin, who covers LGBTQ issues for the non-profit newsroom The 19th, has been following these cases closely.
item.dc:creator: Mia Venkat

item.title: Why we're hooked on documentaries
item.description: NPR's Linda Holmes and Sarah Handel discuss why they are hooked on documentaries and some of the best ones you may not yet have seen.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Linda Holmes and Sarah Handel discuss why they are hooked on documentaries and some of the best ones you may not yet have seen.
item.dc:creator: Sarah McCammon

item.title: How far does Stephen Miller's influence extend in Trump's White House?
item.description: Stephen Miller is largely credited with channeling President Trump's desires and making his vision for the United States real. Ashley Parker, a staff writer for The Atlantic, explains Miller's power within the administration.
item.content:encoded: Stephen Miller is largely credited with channeling President Trump's desires and making his vision for the United States real. Ashley Parker, a staff writer for The Atlantic, explains Miller's power within the administration.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Robbins

item.title: 'ScreenTime' podcast asks what screens are doing to kids
item.description: Andrew Bracken, a journalist at KPBS, on how how his experiences as a parent with technology led to a new podcast.
item.content:encoded: Andrew Bracken, a journalist at KPBS, on how how his experiences as a parent with technology led to a new podcast.
item.dc:creator: Mallory Yu

item.title: Venezuela's exiles in Chile caught between hope and uncertainty
item.description: Initial joy among Venezuela's diaspora in Chile has given way to caution, as questions grow over what Maduro's capture means for the country — and for those who fled it.
item.content:encoded:
Initial joy among Venezuela's diaspora in Chile has given way to caution, as questions grow over what Maduro's capture means for the country — and for those who fled it.

(Image credit: JAVIER TORRES)
item.dc:creator: John Bartlett

item.title: Europe alarmed by Trump's Greenland push
item.description: Europe is increasingly alarmed by Trump's talk of annexing Greenland, an autonomous Danish territory in the EU and NATO, especially after the U.S. incursion in Venezuela last weekend.
item.content:encoded: Europe is increasingly alarmed by Trump's talk of annexing Greenland, an autonomous Danish territory in the EU and NATO, especially after the U.S. incursion in Venezuela last weekend.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Beardsley
